data.title: The great streaming rip off: How Brits are forking out over Â£200 a month to watch the latest shows on services like Disney+, Prime and Netflix - as online calculator totals what YOU are paying
data.meta_description: It was once hailed as the cheaper alternative to a Sky box - but the streaming market is now so fat that Brits face paying triple figures each month trying to keep up with the latest shows.
data.text:
It was once hailed as the cheaper alternative to a Sky box - but the streaming market is now so fat that Brits face paying triple figures each month trying to keep up with the latest shows.

MailOnline research suggests that UK binge-watchers could be spending upwards of Â£200 a month to get the widest range of video on-demand (VoD) content on their TVs and phones across an ever-growing number of platforms.

Picking up subscriptions for some of the UK's most popular streaming services - Netflix, Prime Video, Apple TV+ and Disney+ - will set Brits back between Â£29 and Â£40 a month depending on the packages they choose.

But adding on other platforms like ITVX or a sports package from NOW or TNT Sports (formerly BT Sport) can easily push the monthly cost into triple figures - and experts say the market is at a tipping point.

MailOnline has created a streaming cost calculator that allows you to type in the streaming services you use - and see how much your viewing habits are secretly costing you each month.

An explosion in the number of streaming services means Brits are spoiled for choice when it comes to finding new shows and films to watch: but the selection comes at a literal hefty price.

Joining some of the UK's most popular streaming services - Netflix, Prime Video, Apple TV+ and Disney+ - will set Brits back between Â£29 and Â£40 a month depending on the packages they choose.

But those looking for the widest range of content - from films and TV programmes to live sport - will find themselves paying in excess of Â£200 a month, dwarfing most TV contracts.

It's a far cry from a decade ago, when the streaming market was in its infancy and seen as the challenger to the likes of Sky and Virgin: the only big players were Netflix and Amazon, which snapped up Lovefilm in 2008 and later rebranded it as Prime Video.

A few months after Netflix arrived on British shores in 2012 Sky elbowed its way onto the streaming market with Now TV - offering its film package with no monthly contract.

All three could be purchased for less than Â£40 a month: Netflix at Â£5.99, Lovefilm at Â£4.99, and Now TV's Sky Cinema pass at Â£15.

Streaming platforms cut deals with major film distributors to add their films and TV shows to their libraries - and invested in original shows to lure viewers away from their Sky and Virgin boxes.

Many have been huge hits - from Stranger Things and The Crown on Netflix to The Grand Tour, Clarkson's Farm and The Boys on Prime Video.

But as the streaming firms have raked in cash from subscriptions and cinema numbers fell following the Covid pandemic, distributors have moved in to claim a piece of the pie: Disney, Paramount, Lionsgate, StudioCanal and MGM are among those who have launched their own services.

The move might mean more income - but ordinary viewers lose out in both the choice on their existing services and how much they have to pay to watch everything they want to see.

There are now more than 20 paid-for streaming services available in the UK, from horror specialist Shudder (Â£4.99 a month) to independent curator Mubi (Â£10.99).

Premier League fans will find themselves paying more to get live broadcasts on Sky's NOW Sports pass (Â£34.99) and TNT Sports (Â£29.99), as rights are split across Sky, TNT and Amazon.

Fight fans will need to splash out Â£7.99 for boxing and MMA coverage on DAZN too.

Terrestrial TV platforms offer paid plans too, with Channel 4's ad-free access costing Â£3.99 a month and ITVX offering the Britbox service - with classics such as Only Fools and Horses, Blackadder and Hi-De-Hi! - for Â£5.99.

In short, the market is full: so full, in fact, that it is reaching a 'saturation' point, according to analysis of the market by consultancy Simon Kucher earlier this year - and overwhelmed viewers are switching off in ever-growing numbers.

A July study by consultancy firm Simon Kucher found that the average number of subscriptions held UK households have dropped 10 percent in the last year, with people who cancelled plans saying they had too many subscriptions as is.

Data from market researchers Kantar shows that the number of UK households with at least one VoD subscription fell by 144,000 in April this year to 16.1 million - or around 55% of all UK homes.

Streaming platforms are responding by slashing prices: last year, Netflix launched a Â£4.99 Basic tier with adverts. Earlier this year improved the video quality of the plan and allowed streamers to watch on two devices at once.

But at the same time it has also cracked down on password sharing - requiring account holders to pay for either a Standard or Premium plan, and a Â£4.99 surcharge, if they want to share their account with friends.

However, there are ways to beat the streaming companies at their own game - by shopping around, taking advantage of free trials, cancelling unused subscriptions and switching to free alternatives.

Oli Townsend, assistant deals and features editor at MoneySavingExpert.com, told MailOnline: 'Only subscribing to one streaming service at a time, watching what you want, then cancelling and moving to another is a quick way to save each month.

'With the cost of streaming increasing for many, itâs a good time for consumers to consider how much value theyâre getting from any subscriptions they have, and to look for alternatives if they want to cut back the cost.

'It is important to regularly audit your bank accounts for recurring payments to streaming services, as they can sometimes be forgotten about and tough to spot.

'Some banks show such payments in a dedicated section, often called "subscriptions" or "scheduled payments", so be sure to check if you are using the platforms you are currently subscribed to.

'Use the handy free online tool JustWatch to check which streaming service has the shows or movies you want to see, so that you're only paying for a streaming service you'll actually use.

'If you're subscribed to one but struggle to find something to watch, remember if you're paying monthly, most let you cancel penalty-free at any time.'

Andrew Skeratt, Global Insight Director at Kantar, said the abundance of streaming services was leading to 'boomerang' behaviour from customers, bouncing between one platform to the other.

He claimed Britons were 'adopting and churning services on a more frequent basis', with families 'regularly pivoting' between platforms while trying to keep costs down - with some signing on to cheaper deals featuring adverts.

For those really looking to cut back, there are a number of free streaming platforms available with films and box sets aplenty: from terrestrial services like BBC iPlayer, ITVX, Channel 4 and My5 to others like UKTV Play, live TV platform Pluto and Amazon-owned service Freevee.

But be aware: using iPlayer or watching live TV on any service requires a TV licence.

Mr Townsend added: 'If you're new to streaming services, hop from free trial to free trial to watch premium content for no cost.

'For example, Prime Video gives 30-days free, while Apple TV+, Paramount+ and Lionsgate+ offer a seven-day taster â just remember to cancel the trial before you're charged.'

There are also ways to save money on plans by paying in advance for annual plans.

These require a hefty upfront cost - Â£79.90 on Disney+, Â£43.99 on Hayu and Â£69.90 on Paramount+, to name a few - but Mr Townsend said that those committed to a particular service can save by shopping around before they put their money down.

He summed up: 'Those wanting to watch Disney+ can save in a number of ways, including Â£15 cashback on an annual subscription via Topcashback, three months for Â£12 in Clubcard vouchers, and Â£2 a month off via O2's Priority.

'If you want to stream Prime Video but aren't fussed about Amazon's Prime delivery, then get a Prime Video-only subscription for Â£5.99 a month instead of paying for full Prime membership at Â£8.99 a month.

'You could also consider switching to an annual subscription if you'll use it - Amazon Prime, Paramount+ and Disney+ all offer this option, which can save Â£13 to Â£16 a year.

'And remember, if you only watch streaming services except BBC iPlayer, then you don't need to pay for a TV licence. So if you can, ditch it and save Â£159 a year.'
